title: Shortcuts + NFC Tags
summary: Tap your phone on a $0.50 NFC tag to trigger complex automations. Start your morning routine, log workouts, or control your smart home with a single tap.
editorsNote: Reddit's r/shortcuts notes that NFC automations on iPhone still require a confirmation tap before running (Apple's security restriction), which undermines the 'single tap' promise â€” you actually tap the tag, then tap 'Run' on the notification. Android via Tasker/MacroDroid runs NFC triggers without confirmation. Most iPhone users say the slight friction is worth it for complex multi-step automations.
content:
How to automate your daily routines with a single tap

Every morning you do the same sequence: turn on the lights, check the weather, start a playlist, adjust the thermostat, and open your task manager. Every night: turn off the lights, set the alarm, enable Do Not Disturb, lock the door. Each action takes 10-15 seconds and requires opening a different app. That's 5-8 minutes daily spent on repetitive sequences you've done a thousand times. Smart speakers help, but voice commands are awkward when someone's sleeping, unreliable in noisy environments, and limited to one action at a time. You need a physical trigger that fires a complex sequence instantly.

NFC (Near Field Communication) tags are passive stickers the size of a coin that cost $0.30-0.50 each. When you tap your phone on one, it triggers an automation built in Apple Shortcuts (iOS) or Tasker/MacroDroid (Android). A single tap on a tag stuck to your nightstand can: turn off all lights, lock the front door, set the thermostat to sleep mode, enable Do Not Disturb, set your alarm, and start a sleep sounds playlist â€” all in under 2 seconds. No app to open, no voice command to speak, no buttons to press. The tags need no battery, never wear out, and work through stickers, keychains, and even embedded in furniture.

The standout features are the unlimited customization (each tag triggers a different Shortcuts automation â€” you can have 20 tags around your home each doing something unique), the zero cost for the trigger mechanism ($15 for a 30-pack of tags), and the integration depth with Home Assistant and HomeKit. A tag by your front door can arm the security system, turn off all lights, and send your partner a "leaving now" text. A tag at your gym locker can start a workout timer, toggle Do Not Disturb, and open your exercise app. A tag on your desk can toggle focus mode, start a Pomodoro timer, and open your project management tool.

The real-world impact is eliminating 5-8 minutes of daily routine friction â€” that's 30-50 hours per year. More importantly, it reduces the cognitive overhead of "what do I need to do right now?" into a single physical action. Users report that the physical tap creates a satisfying ritual that reinforces habits better than voice commands or app widgets. The total investment is under $15 for tags and 30 minutes to set up your automations. Compared to a $200 smart speaker that does one thing at a time with voice commands, NFC tags are faster, more reliable, work silently, and cost 1% as much. Combined with the Ecobee thermostat and smart lights, they become the simplest smart home interface possible.

âš¡ Set it up in 5 minutes

  1. Buy NTAG215 NFC tags â€” a 30-pack on Amazon costs $10-15
  2. Open Apple Shortcuts â†’ Automation â†’ New Automation â†’ NFC, and scan a tag to register it
  3. Build your automation sequence â€” add actions for lights, thermostat, messages, apps, music, etc.
  4. Stick the tag where you'll use it: nightstand, desk, front door, gym bag, car dashboard
  5. Tap your phone on the tag to trigger the full sequence
